statement:
Let $F \colon \mathbb{C}^n \to \mathbb{C}^n$ be a polynomial map, i.e.,
$$F(x_1,\dots,x_n) = (f_1(x_1,\dots,x_n), \dots,f_n(x_1,\dots,x_n))$$
for certain polynomials $f_i \in \mathbb{C}[X_1,\dots,X_n]$.

If $F$ is invertible, then its Jacobi determinant
$\det(\partial f_i/\partial
x_j)$, which is a polynomial over $\mathbb{C}$, vanishes nowhere and
hence must be a non-zero constant.

The *Jacobian conjecture* asserts the converse: every polynomial map
$\mathbb{C}^n \to \mathbb{C}^n$ whose Jacobi determinant is a non-zero
constant is invertible.
